I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to Solomon Islands for subprogram 2 of the Economic Recovery Support Program.1 
 
2.  The Economic Recovery Support  Program is a program cluster of two subprogram 
grants totaling $10.0 million.2 The program cluster aims to assist in making the adjustment to an 
economic and fiscal deterioration aggravated by the global economic crisis. Subprogram 2 of 
the program cluster will support improved fiscal management and structural measures that will 
aid economic recovery and place the economy on a sustainable medium-term growth path. 
Budget  support  will  help  protect  the  delivery  of  basic  services  to  the  vulnerable,  and  be 
complemented by actions to engage with key stakeholders. 
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  The Solomon Islands economy has been among the most affected in the Pacific by the 
global economic crisis. Gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaged 7.3% per annum in the 
5 years to 2008. In 2009, GDP contracted by 1.2%. Solomon Islands returned to positive growth 
of  around  7.2%  in  2010.  While  economic  growth  rebounded  quickly,  medium-term  growth 
prospects  are  uncertain.  Stocks  for  the  key  industry—logging—are  expected  to  be  largely 
exhausted by the middle of the decade. The economy is also one of the most aid-dependent in 
the world.  
 
4.  The program cluster was designed to support the Government of Solomon Islands to 
make short-term fiscal adjustments in response to the global financial crisis and lay a foundation 
for strengthening the medium-term reform agenda. Since its initiation, the program has helped 
the  government  weather  the  recent  global  economic  crisis  with  its  financial  position 
strengthened, largely due to the efforts made under the government’s reform program supported 
by  the  Core  Economic  Working  Group  (CEWG)  development  partners.3 The  change  in 
government  in  late  2010  required  additional  time  to  resume  work  on  formulating  and 
implementing policy. The new government, however, remains strongly committed to continuing 
regular and systematic policy dialogue through the CEWG to support the reform program. The 
CEWG donor coordination model in Solomon Islands is considered to be a best-practice model 
of donor coordination in the Pacific.4 The government is now committed to improving the quality 
of public expenditure for better service delivery, as reflected in the government policy statement 
and the new National Development Strategy (NDS) 2011–2020 (currently being finalized). 
 
5.  From subprogram 1 to subprogram 2. Subprogram 1, which was completed in 2010, 
achieved successful policy and institutional reforms. Solomon Islands satisfied all 19 conditions 
for the subprogram 1 grant and the single tranche, totaling $5 million, was fully disbursed.5

Subprogram 2 completes the program reform agenda under the program cluster. In addition, 
after the program completion, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) will continue to be involved in 
providing  policy  advice,  offering  technical  assistance  (TA),  and  monitoring  reform  progress 
against  the  incremental  reforms.6 Subprogram  2  supports  the  government’s  economic  and 
financial reform program in coordination with key development partners including Australia, the 
European  Union,  New  Zealand,  the  Regional  Assistance  Mission  to  Solomon  Islands,  the 
International Monetary Fund (IMF), and the World Bank.  
 
6.  Subprogram 1 has effectively supported recovery from the crisis with growth, and the 
fiscal  and  external  positions  all  significantly  improved  in  2010  compared  with  2009. 7 
Subprogram 2 continues to (i) support the government with the adjustment costs arising from 
implementing an economic reform program to place the economy on a sustainable growth path, 
and (ii) facilitate a diversification of the economy away from unsustainable levels of logging and 
aid. It supports improved fiscal management and structural measures to ensure sustainability of 
the economic recovery and helps protect the delivery of basic services to the vulnerable. 
 
7.  After closely consulting with the government and accounting for evolution of priorities 
and policies, the prior policy actions for subprogram 2 were finalized, closely approximating the 
24 indicative triggers identified at the time of subprogram 1, with two modifications. One of the 
indicative triggers, regarding amendment of the bareboat charter law, was removed in light of a 
consensus that impediments to operation of the franchise shipping scheme had been more 
efficiently addressed with other measures. Another indicative trigger, concerning adoption of the 
Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) principles, was adjusted to recognize that 
Solomon  Islands  has  officially  endorsed  the  principles,  with  the  consequential  legislative 
amendments in the tax regime to be proposed through government undertakings in the grant 
agreement. All 23 prior policy actions and conditions in the policy matrix have been performed 
and satisfied, except for the adoption of NDS, which is at an advanced stage. ADB is currently 
supporting the government in preparing the NDS.8 Completion of the adoption of the NDS is a 
condition to the effectiveness of the grant agreement.   
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The  expected  impact  of  subprogram  2  is  the  achievement  of  a  higher  and  more 
inclusive path of economic growth. The expected outcome is to continue the positive trend of 
economic recovery with protection of the vulnerable and the fiscal position. The impact and 
outcome are to be achieved through reforms in the four program outputs, leading to improved 
fiscal management, an improved enabling environment for the private sector, support for the 
vulnerable,  and  strengthened  communication  and  ownership  of  policy  actions  by  the 
government and the general public. 
 
C.  Outputs 
9.  Subprogram  2  continues  the  policy  and  institutional  reform  actions  begun  under 
subprogram 1. 
                                                 
6  On 9 June 2011, the cabinet endorsed the medium-term policy matrix with triggers and actions to be accomplished 
and assessed annually by the end of 2011, 2012, and 2013. This medium-term policy matrix will be a basis for 
CEWG development partners in providing additional budget support to the government. 
7  Detailed economic and fiscal analyses and the recovery are in Economic Analysis, and detailed macroeconomic 
trends are in Country Economic Indicators (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
8  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to Solomon Islands for Support for the Formulation of a National Strategic Plan. 
Manila (TA 7616-SOL).

3 
 
10.  Output  1:  Improved  fiscal  management.  This output is directed to achieving the 
medium-term goals of achieving overall fiscal discipline, providing strategic guidance to public 
financial  management  (PFM)  reform,  ensuring  effective  expenditure  controls  are  in  use, 
raising the efficiency and fairness of the revenue system, and improving the allocation of 
public  resources  through  strengthened  budgeting  and  planning  processes.  This  output 
supports  short-term  fiscal  consolidation  while  seeking  to  maintain  the  capacity  to  fund 
essential  services  and  public  investment  over  the  medium  term.  The  output  also  helps 
address shortcomings in governance. The emphasis is on initiatives that address the weakest 
areas  of  PFM  identified  in  the  2008  public  expenditure  and  financial  accountability 
assessment.9 ADB operations have also provided additional technical support for achievement 
of output 1 through several TA projects.10 
 
11.  Achieving overall fiscal discipline. Subprograms 1 and 2 provide for adherence by 
the 2010 and 2011 budgets and the medium-term fiscal framework to the fiscal commitments 
of  the  Honiara  Club  Agreement11 (or  any  updated  arrangement  put  in  place  with  the 
international community). Under subprograms 1 and 2, the government committed to keep the 
public debt–GDP ratio below 30% and to keep the ratio of payroll charges to GDP in 2010 to 
no more than the 2009 level. Under the agreement, the government committed to (i) avoid 
further borrowing or sovereign guarantees until the government reaches green light status 
under the international debt distress rating system, and (ii) maintain a fully funded recurrent 
budget  excluding  the  use  of  borrowing  to  fund  recurrent  expenditure.  There  has  been 
compliance with these fiscal provisions. 
 
12.  The 2011 budget, which was approved by the Parliament on 11 April 2011, is consistent 
with fiscal consolidation and was assessed by ADB. The budget is based on the assumption of 
continued economic expansion and, consistent with the Honiara Club Agreement, does not 
envisage new sovereign borrowing. Due attention has been paid to supporting the delivery of 
essential services, with priority given to maintaining recurrent budget for education, health, 
transport, and grants, such as provincial grants, at original 2010 levels, which comfortably 
exceed  the  2009  benchmark  by  an  amount  greater  than  the  value  of  the  ADB  loan.  The 
government's  contribution  to  the  development  budget  has  also  increased  substantially. 
Additional budget support (both general and sectoral) is factored into the budget, including a 
grant of SI$40 million (around $5 million) from ADB. Payroll is estimated at 10.2% of GDP, a 
lower figure than for the previous 2 years as growth in payrolls has been kept below that of 
nominal GDP. A cash cushion of 3 months of recurrent expenditure has been provided for as 
required by the conditions of the IMF program for standby credit facility.12 The IMF mission, 
which  was  fielded  on  3–13  May  2011,  found  that  the  IMF  program  performed  well,  with

13.  Significant fiscal risks nonetheless remain. The key risk factors in the budget include (i) 
the potential for an overestimation of domestic revenue, that is forecast to rise by 12.0%; (ii) the 
prospect of a decline in logging; and (iii) expenditure pressures that may arise from the need for 
the  government  to  accommodate  a  fractious  coalition,  which  may  result  in  a  series  of 
supplementary appropriations. The large wage and salary bill will remain an ongoing source of 
fiscal pressure, and may displace funding for investment and goods and services if the revenue 
outcome is less than expected. 
 
14.  Moving to  multiyear  budgeting and strengthening the budgeting and planning 
processes.  Subprogram  2  provides  for  (i)  commencement  of  a  public  expenditure  review 
(launching  operation  of  the  new  budget  system  with  capacity  to  accommodate  multiyear 
budgeting and integration of recurrent and development budgets), and (ii) instituting the new 
NDS.  The  NDS  has  been  under  formulation  since  early  2010.  In  May  2010,  the  cabinet 
endorsed (i) the national strategy framework, precursor to the NDS; and (ii) an NDS task force 
comprising the Ministry of Finance and Treasury (MOFT), Prime Minister’s Office, the Ministry of 
Development  Planning  and  Aid  Coordination,  and  the  Central  Bank  of  Solomon  Islands. 
Following submission of the first draft NDS in December 2010, intensive work on stakeholder 
consultation is anticipated to conclude with adoption of the NDS by late July or August 2011. 
 
15.  Providing  strategic  guidance  to  public  financial  management  reform.  Under 
subprogram 1, the cabinet endorsed a number of measures to provide high-level strategic 
guidance  to  the  government's  efforts  to  improve  PFM.  Subprogram  2  provides  for 
implementation of the strategies to improve whole-of-government financial reporting and internal 
audit. These actions are oriented towards the long-term goal of receiving an unqualified audit 
opinion on the whole-of-government accounts. 
 
16.  Ensuring effective expenditure controls are in use. The program has assisted the 
process of fiscal consolidation by strengthening expenditure controls including (i) upgrades to 
the financial management information and payroll systems, (ii) preparation and adoption of new 
financial instructions, and (iii) cabinet endorsement of strategies to modernize supply chain 
management (procurement) procedures under subprogram 1. Subprogram 2 provides for (i) 
implementing  new  financial  instructions,  (ii)  “cleansing”  the  payroll  data  to  increase  the 
effectiveness of the new payroll system introduced in subprogram 1, and (iii) implementing the 
mechanisms to tighten expenditure controls. Procurement compliance has been strengthened, 
with the revised financial instructions becoming operational with effect from 1 July 2010.14 
 
17.  Raising the efficiency and fairness of the revenue system. The Medium-Term Fiscal 
Strategy 2008–2013 outlined the government’s commitment to further tax reform. Key objectives 
are  to  broaden  the  tax  base,  shift  reliance  away  from  direct  taxes,  and  simplify  the 
administration of tax, both for the government and for taxpayers. Subprogram 2 provides for the 
adoption of cross-government revenue management enhancements covering legislative and 
operational  reform,  endorsement  of  EITI,  preparation  of  a  new  tax  regime  for  the  mining 
industry, and commencement of a review of the Customs Act, overseen by a high-level steering 
committee. Subprograms 1 and 2 demonstrated concrete progress in revenue management by 
MOFT and its subordinated agencies.  By a cabinet decision on 19 May 2011, the government

initiated  a  broader  cross  government  strategy  for  coordinating  revenue  management 
enhancement in other branches such as land and fisheries. 
 
18.  Output  2:  Productivity  enhancing  structural  initiatives.  This output implements 
structural initiatives with the potential for short-term boosts in economic activity and those 
reforms needed to achieve medium-term rebuilding of economic growth. A key concern is 
diversifying the economy away from logging and foreign aid towards alternative sources of 
growth—agriculture  (primarily  palm  oil,  cocoa,  and  copra),  fishing  and  marine  products, 
mining, and tourism.15 
 
19.  There are four areas of focus under this output: (i) improving the efficiency and reducing 
the  drain  of  state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  on  the  budget,  which  should  in  turn  reduce 
crowding out of the private sector; (ii) deregulating the telecommunications industry to expand 
service coverage, raise standards, and lower prices; (iii) enhancing the business regulatory 
environment  to  directly  reduce  the  cost  of  doing  business  in  Solomon  Islands;  and  (iv) 
developing the transport infrastructure to raise investment levels and service standards and 
lower transport operating costs. 
 
20.  Improving accountability and performance of state-owned enterprises. Subprogram 
2 provides for (i) public release of an annual SOE  monitoring report,16 (ii) endorsing debt 
restructuring for the Solomon Islands Electricity Authority (SIEA) and new appointments to 
senior positions, (iii) completing the tender process for sale of Sasape Marina and initiating a 
restructure of Solomon Airlines, and (iv) implementing SOE regulations on community service 
obligations and appointing directors with a view to further enhancing performance. Subprogram 
2 requires further actions to resolve the debt that the Solomon Islands Water Authority (SIWA) 
owes to the SIEA (more than SI$20 million). A joint donor program—the Pacific Regional 
Infrastructure Facility—is currently funding advisory assistance to SIWA. An output from this 
assistance includes completing the recovery action plan, which includes proposed measures to 
settle SIWA’s debt to the SIEA. 
 
21.  Deregulating the telecommunications industry. The program provides for the end of 
the legislated monopoly on mobile telecommunications. Under subprogram 1, the voluntary 
relinquishment  of  the  existing  operator's  exclusive  license  was  completed  and  new 
telecommunications legislation was enacted. Subprogram 2 provides for the continuation of this 
process  through  the  commencement  of  operations  of  an  independent  regulator.  The 
Telecommunications Commission has been operating as the independent telecommunications 
regulator with a self-funding mandate. 
 
22.  Reducing the cost of doing business. The government is implementing a number of 
reforms aimed at reducing the cost of doing business and ensuring a level playing field for all 
businesses. The Companies Act 2009 and the Companies (Insolvency and Receiverships) Act 
2009 and associated regulations were gazetted and commenced on 1 July 2010. The new 
company registry commenced operation on the same day with paper-based registration; the 
new electronic registry successfully went live in December 2010. To ensure sustainability of the

23.  Developing  transport  infrastructure.  Subprogram  2  provides  for  (i)  updating  the 
national  transport  plan  to  implement  an  updated  3-year  rolling  work  program,  and  (ii) 
implementing  the  franchise  shipping  scheme  and  Solomon  Islands  Maritime  Safety 
Administration. Redesign of shipping routes and insurance coverage was introduced to bring 
about  timely  modification  and  successful  operation  of  the  scheme  without  the  need  for 
legislative revisions earlier anticipated during subprogram 1. 
 
24.  Output  3:  Support  for  the  vulnerable.  The  budget  support  provided  under  the 
program  cluster  will  allow  a  slightly  higher  level  of  government  expenditure  than  would 
otherwise be possible. Additional financial resources provided by ADB will reduce the national 
budget's financing gap and thereby help preserve the delivery of basic transport services, rural 
health  services,  and  basic  education.  The  increased  budget  allocation  for  education  and 
health is more critical for females than males in Solomon Islands, given the current gender 
gap in these sectors. Specifically, the government made commitments under subprogram 2 
regarding the additional allocation of its own funds under the 2011 recurrent budget to goods 
and services (i.e., nonpayroll costs) to education, health, and infrastructure services. These 
additional funds are at least equal to the level of the grant provided under subprogram 1. The 
2011 recurrent budget, less the sum of the payroll and development budgets, provided an 
additional  allocation  of  SI$157  million  from  2009  levels  for  education,  health,  and 
infrastructure services, which substantially exceeds the grant of approximately SI$40 million 
provided under subprogram 2. 
 
25.  Output 4: Communication and ownership of policy actions. Under subprogram 2, a 
communications and engagement strategy is being developed to explain the government’s 
response  to  the  global  economic  crisis,  including  (i)  actions  to  address  the  needs  of  the 
vulnerable, (ii) the state of public finances and PFM reform, and (iii) structural initiatives. Public 
release of key fiscal information has been expanded to include debt statistics and operation of 
an MOFT website. The engagement strategy developed in consultation with stakeholders was 
endorsed by the cabinet in May 2011. 
 
D.  Program Costs and Financing 
26.  The government has requested a grant17 not exceeding $5 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds  resources  to  help  finance  the  program.  The  grant  size  was  determined  after  due 
consideration of (i) the estimated impact of the global economic crisis and the associated overall 
projected financing requirements for the national budget, which is estimated by the IMF at $25 
million  annually  in  2010  and  2011;  (ii)  the  availability  of  additional  finance  from  other 
development partners; (iii) the significance and complexity of the policy actions of the program, 
which are expected to generate substantial development benefits; and (iv) the grant proceeding, 
thereby  allowing  the  government  to  expand  budget  expenditure  for  public  services  thus 
protecting  vulnerable  populations  from  adverse  impacts of  the  global  economic  crisis.  The 
determination of grant size took into account the government's demonstrated commitment to, 
and progress in implementing, the policy agenda. 
                                                 
17 A country's eligibility for Asian Development Fund grants under the revised grant framework is determined by its risk 
of debt distress. The latest debt sustainability analysis in the IMF 2009 Article IV Consultation determined that 
Solomon Islands had a moderate risk of debt distress and was therefore eligible to receive 50% of its ADF allocation 
as grants.

7 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
27.  The program cluster period spans from 1 March 2009 to 28 February 2012, with the 
subprogram 2 implementation period embracing 1 March 2010 to 28 February 2012 with post-
program partnership monitoring efforts with other CEWG members to continue through 2013. 
Subprogram 2 funding will be provided as a single tranche grant of $5 million to be disbursed 
when the government has met the conditions for effectiveness including completion of the 
agreed prior policy actions as set forth in the policy matrix.18 
 
28.  The  proceeds  of  the  grant  will  be  disbursed  to  Solomon  Islands  as  the  recipient 
according to ADB’s simplified disbursement procedures and related requirements for program 
grants.19 The proceeds will be used to finance items produced and procured in ADB member 
countries;  items  in  the  list  of  ineligible  items  and  imports  financed  by  other  bilateral  and 
multilateral sources are excluded.20 Grant proceeds disbursed against imports will require a 
certificate from the government stipulating that the value of the total imports of Solomon Islands, 
minus its imports from nonmember countries, ineligible imports, and imports financed under 
other  official  development  assistance,  is  at  least  equal  to  the  amount  of  the  grant  to  be 
disbursed during a particular year. Local currency generated from the proceeds of the grants will 
be used to support public expenditure objectives under the program. 
 
29.  The MOFT will be the executing and implementing agency and will oversee policy, legal, 
and regulatory actions and ensure that the policy actions as agreed upon by the government 
and ADB are duly carried out on time. Several ongoing ADB TA projects (footnotes 10 and 15) 
are assisting the government in (i) implementing the reforms and meeting tranche conditions in 
the short term, and (ii) building the government’s capacity in the medium and long term. The 
MOFT is responsible for overall implementation of subprogram 2, including carrying out all 
policy actions, program administration, disbursements, and maintenance of all program records. 
The MOFT will (i) establish and maintain a performance evaluation system for the program, 
which will be derived from the design and monitoring framework, policy letter, and policy matrix; 
and (ii) monitor and report to ADB, on a biannual basis over the term of the program, the 
implementation of policy actions and their impact on budget outcomes, in line with the program 
impact and outcome indicators agreed upon with the government. Monitoring of outcomes and 
impacts will maximize use of the government’s own processes and the CEWG mechanism. 
 
30.  In  cooperation  with  the  MOFT  and  CEWG,  ADB  will  carry  out  periodic  reviews  of 
progress implementation and assess the impact of the program, which continues from the well-
functioning practice under subprogram 1.21 The government will continue to keep ADB informed 
of the outcome of policy discussions with other multilateral and bilateral agencies that have 
implications for program implementation, and will provide ADB with the opportunity to comment 
on any resulting policy proposals. ADB, in collaboration with the MOFT and key multilateral and 
bilateral agencies via the CEWG, will undertake regular reviews of program performance. The 
reviews will evaluate implementation of the policy reform measures and assess the impact, 
describe  lessons  identified  during  the  program  period,  and  outline  policy  actions  and  any 
assistance needed for sustained economic recovery. The program reviews and the design of 
subprogram 2 have drawn on dialogue with stakeholders from the private sector and civil

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
31.  Economic  growth  prospects  for  Solomon  Islands  rest  on  the  private  sector  and  on 
developments in mining, agriculture, fishing, and, to a lesser extent, tourism. A large gold mine 
closed during the civil unrest has recently reopened in March 2011, and there is potential over 
the longer term to develop large nickel deposits. While mining projects would boost GDP, the 
sector would employ few people and there would be long lags before government revenue rose. 
The best prospects for job creation and for higher government revenue lie in large-scale palm oil 
developments, in fishing (there is already one large fish cannery), and in the smallholder tree 
crops  of  cocoa  and  copra.  The  supply  of  fruit  and  vegetables  to  the  urban  centers  as  a 
substitute for imports also offers good prospects, as does the fledgling tourism industry. 
 
32.  A number of recent studies have examined the economic growth prospects allowing for 
different scenarios. The studies have identified the potential for economic growth after logging, 
albeit at only low to moderate rates that would see, at best, slow growth in real GDP per capita 
in the medium term. The studies have also highlighted the need for concerted government 
action to realize the potential growth, and the risk of inaction. 
 
B.  Governance 
33.  Public financial management. The quality of public sector financial management has 
been improved in recent years. The government has embarked on a series of public expenditure 
reforms, including clearing the backlog of unaudited central government financial statements, 
introducing a medium-term fiscal framework, paying debt interest and trade creditor arrears, and 
increasing  revenue  collection.  However,  a  number  of  weaknesses  remain  in  public  sector 
financial management that adversely affect public service delivery, threaten aggregate fiscal 
discipline,  and  undermine  the  strategic  allocation  of  public  resources.  To  address  the 
weaknesses, the government and development partners continue to deepen the reforms that 
simultaneously strengthen the government’s institutions and capacity.22 
 
34.  Anticorruption.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained 
to and discussed with the government and the MOFT. The specific policy requirements and 
supplementary measures are described in the legal documents and the grant regulations. 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
35.  Through all four main program outputs, policy reforms are expected to have significant 
poverty and social benefits. Reforms under the first output of improved fiscal management allow 
the government to dedicate more resources to pro-poor expenditure. Improvements in budget 
processes are expected to lead to more efficient service delivery. Policy actions under the 
second  output  to  enhance  productivity  are  aimed  at  increasing  economic  activities  and 
investment. Promoting private sector development was designed to support economic growth,

job creation, business opportunities, improved livelihood, and poverty reduction. More specific 
support for the vulnerable is featured in the third output by requiring an increased share of 
recurrent budget funding for basic education, health, and rural transport services, in recognition 
of the extra hardship imposed by the global economic crisis and the preceding episode of high 
international commodity prices. Essential public services used by the most vulnerable (basic 
transport, health, and education services) have been identified, and ADB grant resources will 
help maintain budget expenditure in 2011 on the goods and services used in their delivery. The 
policy actions under the fourth output enhance the voice of the population, including poor people 
and women, regarding policy formulation and implementation. 
 
36.  The policy reforms under the program cluster have indirect impacts on gender equality 
and  empowerment  of  women.  Given  the  current  gender  gap  in  education  and  health,  the 
increased budget is expected to benefit more women. While the policy reforms under the 
program  may  make  a  limited  and  indirect  contribution  to  gender  equality  and  women’s 
empowerment, the improved PFM will have indirect benefits for poor people, who rely most on 
public services as they cannot afford alternative services. The budget increase can be linked to 
women’s  improved  access  to  basic  education  services  and  health  services,  particularly 
reproductive health services. The program requires monitoring of women’s improved access to 
health and basic education services as indicated in the design and monitoring framework.23 
 
D.  Safeguards 
37.  The  program  is  classified  as  category  C  with  no  significant  adverse  environmental 
impacts identified. No involuntary resettlement or impacts on indigenous people are expected.  
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
38.  The program is designed in line with the government’s 2011 budget and 2010–2012 
medium-term fiscal framework. The key assumptions underlying the program include that (i) 
domestic political and macroeconomic stability is maintained, (ii) the global economy recovers 
from the financial crisis, and (iii) the government continues to be committed to improved fiscal 
management and performance. Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 1 
and also described in detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.24

IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
39.  The government and MOFT have assured ADB that implementation of the program 
cluster  and  subprogram  2  shall  conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those 
concerning anticorruption measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and 
disbursement as described in detail in the grant documents. 
 
40.  Specific  assurances.  In  addition  to  the  standard  assurances,  the  government  and 
MOFT have given the following assurances, which are incorporated in the legal documents: (i) 
the government will (a) maintain the policies adopted and actions taken under subprogram 1 
and subprogram 2 prior to the date of the grant agreement for subprogram 2, as described in 
the  development  policy  letter  and  the  policy  matrix,  for  the  duration  of  the  program  and 
subsequently; (b) promptly adopt the other policies and the other actions as specified in the 
development policy letter and the policy matrix; and (c) ensure that such policies and actions 
continue in effect for the duration of the program and subsequently; and (ii) the government and 
the  program  implementing  agencies  will  ensure  that,  throughout  the  implementation  of 
subprogram 2, adequate budgetary allocations of the required counterpart funds are made, 
approved, and released in a timely manner to ensure proper program implementation. 
 
41.  Condition  for  grant  effectiveness.  The  grant  will  become  effective  after  the 
government has satisfactorily fulfilled all conditions for the release of the single tranche of 
subprogram 2. Adoption of the NDS, anticipated by late July or August 2011, is the only 
outstanding item among these conditions.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
42.  I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  grant  not 
exceeding $5,000,000 to Solomon Islands from ADB’s Special Funds resources for subprogram 
2 of the Economic Recovery Support Program, on terms and conditions that are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the Board.
